head.supplied: Browns Camp ¶ 20/5/89. ¶ ¶ […] ¶ ¶ Yesterday I ascended the Tingiringi Mountain again in order to obtain more flowering specimens of the doubtful Eucalypt, but unfortunately it had flowered off, so ...

div.p: MRS 203, Inwards correspondence — special bundles, 1886-1921 Item 1, 89/186, Archives of the Powerhouse Museum, Sydney

Yesterday I ascended the Tingiringi Mountain again in order to obtain more flowering specimens of the doubtful Eucalypt, but unfortunately it had flowered off, so that all I obtained in the shape of flowers were a few pretty well past flowering but still showing some of the stamens with a few of the anthers , and I think there can be no doubt that they belong to the "Parallelantherae". All I got I shall require to send to Baron von Muller but I obtained more specimens of the fruit in various stages. ... I am able to send a complete set of specimens of this [second] species to Baron von Muller; and at the same time a set with bark of our first species. […] The bark of the second species has also the white secretion which some of the Viminalis group have. I am hower [however] still of opinion that the specimens I sent to Baron von Muller two years ago were of the first species, though at the time I took no further notice of the bark than that it was quite smooth. […] It is a great pity that Baron von Muller did not tell me sooner that he required more flowers, then I might have obtained them […]
Not relevant.
